contexts.context: [Preceding: If filter options are available, they will be shown next to the Date Range picker, or below it on narrow/mobile viewports. Available filters for each report are covered more in-depth in the documentation for each report.]

contexts.alt: From WooCommerce 10
contexts.context: [Preceding: From WooCommerce 10.5, Analytics now includes a Data Status Indicator and a manual ‘Update Now’ button to show when analytics data was last updated. This allows you to trigger imports on demand.]

contexts.alt: The Summary Number tabs give you a quick view of the total figure for that metric over the period se
contexts.context: [Preceding: The Summary Number tabs give you a quick view of the total figure for that metric over the period selected, the total number for the period being compared, and the percentage trend between those two figures. Select one of the Summary Number tabs to view that particular metric in the chart.]

contexts.alt: The charts on report screens offer quite a few options to customize the visualization of data
contexts.context: [Preceding: The charts on report screens offer quite a few options to customize the visualization of data. First, the Data Legend checkboxes allow you to toggle the visibility of different data set periods. For example, the selected range and the range to compare against. Next, the Interval Selector allows you to adjust the interval displayed in the chart such as by day, week, month, or quarter. The options available in the Interval selector are dependent upon the length of the date range selected. And lastly, you can adjust the Type of Chart being displayed, either a line or bar chart.]

contexts.alt: The table which displays the detailed data on Analytics reports also has a number of features that a
contexts.context: [Preceding: The table which displays the detailed data on Analytics reports also has a number of features that allow you to customize how the data is displayed, and an option to download a CSV copy of the data used in the report for further analysis.]

contexts.alt: If a report contains a data column that you don’t need to be displayed, you can adjust the visibilit
contexts.context: [Preceding: If a report contains a data column that you don’t need to be displayed, you can adjust the visibility of it by using the visibility menu on the right side of the table header. Toggle the column name in the menu to change the visibility of the column. Your visibility selections are persisted to your user preferences for each report, so on subsequent visits to that report, the columns you have previously disabled will not be displayed.]

contexts.alt: When the data displayed in the table is larger than the default single page size of 25, pagination o
contexts.context: [Preceding: When the data displayed in the table is larger than the default single page size of 25, pagination options will appear in the table footer area. You can move forward and backward through the pages using the directional arrow buttons or enter a number in the text field to jump to a specific page. Furthermore, you can change the number of rows to display per page.]

contexts.alt: Some reports also provide a search box to filter and compare data
contexts.context: [Preceding: Some reports also provide a search box to filter and compare data. For details on what the search box does on a given report, please refer to the report’s documentation.]

contexts.alt: To customize dashboard sections, use the customization menu (three vertical dots) in the top right c
contexts.context: [Preceding: To customize dashboard sections, use the customization menu (three vertical dots) in the top right corner of the section title. The first item that appears in this menu is the ability to toggle the display of the various stats that are shown in the section.]

contexts.alt: The Date Type field is set to Date Paid by default, but might be unset on older installs.
contexts.context: [Preceding: Select the date field that should be considered for Revenue and Order Reports such as Date created, Date paid, or Date completed. The default date type is “Date Paid.”]

contexts.alt: WooCommerce 10
contexts.context: [Preceding: WooCommerce 10.5 introduces a Update setting that controls how scheduled analytics imports are processed.]

contexts.alt: Select “Start” when you’re ready for the import to begin
contexts.context: [Preceding: Select “Start” when you’re ready for the import to begin. The import will run in the background so it’s safe to navigate away from this page without affecting the import. You can return to Analytics > Settings at any time to monitor import progress.]

contexts.alt: Once you’ve started an import, the number of imported customers and orders will be periodically upda
contexts.context: [Preceding: Once you’ve started an import, the number of imported customers and orders will be periodically updated on the Analytics > Settings screen. If you need to stop the import at any time, select “Stop Import.” Data already imported will not be affected.]

contexts.alt: If you need to reset the Analytics reports after importing historical data, you can do so from this
contexts.context: [Preceding: If you need to reset the Analytics reports after importing historical data, you can do so from this settings screen by selecting Delete Previously Imported Data. Once that data is deleted your reports won’t show any information and you’ll want to re-import historical data, say a new time frame, or wait on new orders and customers to come in.]

contexts.alt: To customize the widgets displayed on the dashboard, select “Screen Options” in the upper right corn
contexts.context: [Preceding: To customize the widgets displayed on the dashboard, select “Screen Options” in the upper right corner of the screen to open the Screen elements panel. The options displayed here depend on what plugins you have installed, what page you’re on, whether multisite is enabled, and even what hosting company you’re using.]

contexts.alt: If you haven’t completed the WooCommerce Setup Wizard, you’ll see the WooCommerce Setup widget on th
contexts.context: [Preceding: If you haven’t completed the WooCommerce Setup Wizard, you’ll see the WooCommerce Setup widget on the dashboard as a reminder to configure necessary store settings. Once the WooCommerce Setup Wizard is completed, the WooCommerce Status and WooCommerce Recent Reviews widgets will show and be available in the screen options panel.]

contexts.context: [Preceding: It will show if you have orders waiting to be processed or on-hold. It will also show the number of products running low on stock or completely out of stock.]

contexts.alt: Note: If you selected either Force Downloads or X-Accel-Redirect/X-Sendfile then you have the option
contexts.context: [Preceding: Note: If you selected either Force Downloads or X-Accel-Redirect/X-Sendfile then you have the option to enable the “Allow using redirect mode (insecure) as a last resort” setting. Enabling this setting allows the “redirect method” to be used if a file cannot be delivered/served to your customer using your selected method (Forced Downloads or X-Accel-Redirect). This comes with the same risks as the “redirect only” method described above, but is helpful in cases where you host assets across different platforms that may not work with your preferred method.]

contexts.context: [Preceding: This field also auto-generates a slug for new products, which is the final segment of a product’s URL. The field accepts letters, numbers, special characters, emojis, and even HTML. Changing the title of an existing product does not alter the slug. To change the slug, you can use the “Edit” button that appears next to the URL below the Product name field after the initial save, or you can modify it through the Slug panel.]

contexts.context: [Preceding: At the top of the box is Product type which always defaults to Simple product. Next to it are two checkboxes, Virtual and Downloadable. The state of these three together influences the visibility and content of each of the sections in this panel. The default sections are General, Inventory, Shipping, Linked Products, Attributes, Advanced, and Get more options.]

contexts.alt: In the Linked Products section, you can add products for cross-promotion as upsells (a product that
contexts.context: [Preceding: In the Linked Products section, you can add products for cross-promotion as upsells (a product that is more beneficial for you or your customer) or cross-sells (a complementary product). Add products by clicking in the respective field, searching, and selecting a result. This section is available for all product types.]

contexts.alt: An illustration showing an example product, the Comfy Chair 3000, with an upsell below it suggesting the Comfy Chair 4000.
contexts.context: [Preceding: For example, if a customer looks at the Comfy Chair 3000 while browsing for office chairs, you could offer the Comfy Chair 4000 as an upsell. (It has a cup holder!) It also has better profit margins, making it a more beneficial sale for you too.]

contexts.alt: An illustration showing an example product, the Comfy Chair 4000, with a cross sell below it suggesting the vacuum flask.
contexts.context: [Preceding: To extend our above example, if the customer opted to purchase the Comfy Chair 4000 for its cup holder, we suspect they value having a drink nearby. Based on this, we can present a vacuum flask as a cross-sell as it’s custom-made for the chair’s cup holder — the perfect complement.]

contexts.alt: Payment Information in the Order Notes
contexts.context: [Preceding: In the screenshot above, the order screen shows that the payment was made via a credit card and the transaction ID. In some cases, the specific payment gateway used will appear at the top of the order details, alongside the method used. As this isn’t always the case, we’ll show you how to find this information in the order notes below:]

contexts.alt: Make sure the payment gateway is set to both Authorize and Capture the charge, and not just authoriz
contexts.context: [Preceding: Make sure the payment gateway is set to both Authorize and Capture the charge, and not just authorize it. An authorization is a hold on funds, requiring the store owner to manually “capture” the charge before any money is transferred. Authorize and Capture is much more common, and is a single-step process that immediately transfers funds from your customer to your payment gateway. You can check if this is the case by looking at the order notes and checking that the payment was authorized, but not captured:]

contexts.alt: Payment Logs
contexts.context: [Preceding: If you can’t find anything useful or insightful in the order notes, check WooCommerce logs for errors or any clues about issues with the communication between the payment gateway and your store. If logging is enabled in your payment gateway’s settings, you can find the logs in WooCommerce > Status > Logs. You will want to look for the logs of the payment gateway used in the affected order for the day the order was placed. Please know that once logging is enabled, the system will only capture new transactions. This means you may need to place a test order to generate logs. If you find any logs for the payment being initiated, but not finished, this could indicate that the process was interrupted or failed silently after the initial request. If you find this is the case, you may want to contact your payment gateway’s support or contact our support for WooCommerce-developed payment gateways.]

contexts.alt: Note #1: Loco Translate offers three different locations for where to create the translation
contexts.context: [Preceding: Note #1: Loco Translate offers three different locations for where to create the translation. The best choice for your own translation is Custom, not just to prevent custom translations from being undone by updates, but also because it’s needed for strings in extensions like WooCommerce Subscriptions to be properly translated. Avoid the Author location since it’s inside the plugin and will be overwritten by extension updates, as well as the System location, which could be overwritten by translations from translate.wordpress.org.Note #2: If you encounter any technical issues while using Loco Translate, please get in touch with the Loco Translate support team.]

contexts.alt: Four on-sale products displayed using the products shortcode.
contexts.context: [Preceding: This shortcode explicitly states four products with four columns (which will be one row), showing the most popular on-sale items. It also adds the quick-sale CSS class, which we can target and modify using custom CSS.]

contexts.alt: Four featured products displayed using the products shortcode.
contexts.context: [Preceding: This shortcode specifies that up to four products will load in two columns and that they must be featured. We did not use the orderby attribute, so the shortcode will display products in the default sorting (by menu order, then by title, listed A to Z by default as order is not used).]

contexts.alt: Three best-selling products displayed using the products shortcode.
contexts.context: [Preceding: Here’s how you would display three top best-selling products in one row:]

contexts.alt: Four products displayed with their individual post IDs superimposed over them.
contexts.context: [Preceding: In this example, we’ll display the newest products first — four products across one row. To accomplish this, we’ll use Post ID (which increases incrementally with new posts, and is generated when the product page is created), along with the order and orderby command. Since you can’t see the Post ID from the front end, the ID numbers have been superimposed over the images.]

contexts.alt: Products in the 'tshirts' and 'hoodies' categories displayed using the products shortcode.
contexts.context: [Preceding: Here’s how to display hoodies and shirts, but not accessories. We’ll configure it to display in two rows of four:]

contexts.alt: Products not in the 'tshirts' and 'hoodies' categories displayed using the products shortcode.
contexts.context: [Preceding: Note: Even though the limit is set as 8, only four products that fit that criteria, so four products are displayed.]

contexts.alt: Products with an attribute of 'warm' displayed using the products shortcode.
contexts.context: [Preceding: Each item of clothing has an attribute — either “Spring/Summer” or “Fall/Winter”, depending on the appropriate season — with some accessories having both as they can be worn all year. In this example, there are three products per row, displaying all of the “Spring/Summer” items. The attribute slug is season; the attribute’s terms are warm and cold. We’ve also sorted the products from newest to oldest.]

contexts.alt: Products that do not have an attribute of 'warm' displayed using the products shortcode.
contexts.context: [Preceding: Alternatively, if we want to display everything but warm-weather products, we could add NOT IN as my terms_operator:]

contexts.alt: Products with the 'hoodie' tag displayed using the products shortcode.
contexts.context: [Preceding: Note: By using NOT IN, we exclude products that are both in “Spring/Summer” and “Fall/Winter”. If we want to show all cold-weather appropriate gear including these shared accessories, we would change the term from warm to cold.]

contexts.context: [Preceding: The Revenue Report as the name implies provides insight into the revenue of your store. The date range defaults to the default range you’ve chosen under Analytics > Settings, but you can use that dropdown to filter by any range of time. There’s also the option to compare your chosen date range to the previous period or previous year as well.Right below the Date range: selection you’ll see cards summarizing Gross sales, Returns, Coupons, Net sales, Taxes, Shipping, and Total sales. This will also show the percentage changed if comparing to a previous period. You can select any of these cards to then show that data in the chart below.]

contexts.alt: Once you’ve selected “Capture Charge” and saved the order, payments will be captured via the payment
contexts.context: [Preceding: Once you’ve selected “Capture Charge” and saved the order, payments will be captured via the payment gateway, the order status will update to “processing”, and the Order notes will be updated to reflect these changes (the gateway name will vary in the order notes):]

contexts.alt: Bulk capturing charges is also possible
contexts.context: [Preceding: Bulk capturing charges is also possible. Select the orders for which you want to capture charges on the “Orders” page, then use the bulk “Capture Charge” action to update all selected orders:]

contexts.alt: This setting must be enabled to process auto-captures
contexts.context: [Preceding: This setting must be enabled to process auto-captures.]

contexts.alt: These payment methods allow for partial captures, meaning more than one payment capture can be proce
contexts.context: [Preceding: These payment methods allow for partial captures, meaning more than one payment capture can be processed for an order, with a custom amount of your choosing for the capture. This must be enabled in the plugin settings.]

contexts.alt: To perform a partial capture, edit the order, and click “Capture charge” for the order actions
contexts.context: [Preceding: To perform a partial capture, edit the order, and click “Capture charge” for the order actions.]

contexts.alt: You can then enter the desired amount for the capture, and can process the capture
contexts.context: [Preceding: You can then enter the desired amount for the capture, and can process the capture. You can repeat this action until the total possible capture amount has been used.]

contexts.alt: To process an automatic refund, the “Refund via Credit Card” (or “Refund via {Gateway Name}” if you’
contexts.context: [Preceding: To process an automatic refund, the “Refund via Credit Card” (or “Refund via {Gateway Name}” if you’ve changed the payment method title) option must be used when creating the refund. This will send the refund information to the payment gateway to process the refund.]

contexts.alt: For a partial refund, selecting “Refund with Credit Card” will process the refund and create an orde
contexts.context: [Preceding: For a partial refund, selecting “Refund with Credit Card” will process the refund and create an order note to designate the amount that was refunded via the payment gateway.]

contexts.alt: For total refunds, the refund amount will be added to an order note, but the order status will also
contexts.context: [Preceding: For total refunds, the refund amount will be added to an order note, but the order status will also be updated. If the total amount is completely refunded via this gateway, the order status will be changed to “refunded”, and an additional order note is added for the status change.]

contexts.alt: Transactions can be voided by using the same workflow as refunds
contexts.context: [Preceding: Transactions can be voided by using the same workflow as refunds. A void will occur if the transaction has been authorized, but not captured. For most payment gateways, voids will also occur for authorized & captured transactions that have not yet been settled in the payment gateway account. As funds haven’t been transferred, a refund can’t truly be processed.]

contexts.alt: The enhanced checkout form provides an improved checkout experience over the default WooCommerce pay
contexts.context: [Preceding: The enhanced checkout form provides an improved checkout experience over the default WooCommerce pay form. This form provides larger input fields, auto-formatted card numbers, automatic card-type icon display, auto-formatted expiration dates, and retina card icons.]

contexts.alt: Mobile Credit Card Form
contexts.context: [Caption: Mobile Credit Card Form]

contexts.alt: Mobile eCheck Form
contexts.context: [Caption: Mobile eCheck Form]

contexts.alt: For any payment gateway that supports saved methods, these methods can be managed from the account t
contexts.context: [Preceding: For any payment gateway that supports saved methods, these methods can be managed from the account to set a default or delete saved methods. However, these gateways support enhanced saved methods, which have a few extra features. First, the items can use nicknames (such as “Personal” or “Business”), making it easy for your customers to identify the item at checkout. The nickname can be added by clicking the “edit” action for the method.]

contexts.alt: Next, these methods will also use nicknames at checkout so customers can identify their saved cards
contexts.context: [Preceding: Next, these methods will also use nicknames at checkout so customers can identify their saved cards easily.]

contexts.alt: However, these gateways also support adding a saved payment method from the “My account” section usi
contexts.context: [Preceding: However, these gateways also support adding a saved payment method from the “My account” section using an “Add Payment Method” workflow. Customers can add a saved payment method by going to their My Account page and scrolling to the “My Payment Methods” section. This will list any linked methods, along with the payment method type.]

contexts.alt: To avoid this, when Subscriptions is active, the “My Payment Methods” table adapts to it and disable
contexts.context: [Preceding: To avoid this, when Subscriptions is active, the “My Payment Methods” table adapts to it and disables deletion of methods tied to subscriptions.]

contexts.alt: If the gateway provides a response code that can display a useful message, such as CVV mismatch or z
contexts.context: [Preceding: If the gateway provides a response code that can display a useful message, such as CVV mismatch or zip code mismatch, the payment gateway will instead display a more intelligent message to the customer to help them successfully complete checkout.]

contexts.alt: You can access the token editor from the “Edit User” page, right before customer billing details
contexts.context: [Preceding: You can access the token editor from the “Edit User” page, right before customer billing details.]

contexts.alt: Note that some gateways may have additional information, depending on what the gateway requires for
contexts.context: [Preceding: Note that some gateways may have additional information, depending on what the gateway requires for using tokens. For example, Authorize.Net CIM will show Customer ID (necessary for charging a token). The token editor may also show other information if stored in the gateway (such as the Shipping profile ID in AuthNet CIM).]

contexts.alt: When any block inside the main Cart block is selected, you’ll see an option in the block toolbar to
contexts.context: [Preceding: When any block inside the main Cart block is selected, you’ll see an option in the block toolbar to adjust which state you’re viewing. You can also select Filled Cart or Empty Cart blocks via the List View to display the appropriate state.]

contexts.alt: The Cart Items section includes a block displaying the line items in the cart, as well as a subsecti
contexts.context: [Preceding: The Cart Items section includes a block displaying the line items in the cart, as well as a subsection displaying cross-sells.]

contexts.alt: When a new Cart block is added, the Cross-Sells section is now automatically powered by the Product
contexts.context: [Preceding: When a new Cart block is added, the Cross-Sells section is now automatically powered by the Product Collection block. By suggesting complementary products in the cart using cross-sells, you can significantly increase the average order value.]

contexts.alt: The Newest Products block allows you to control the number of products displayed, and choose whether
contexts.context: [Preceding: The Newest Products block allows you to control the number of products displayed, and choose whether or not to show additional details (such as product image, title, price, rating, add to cart button, etc.).]

contexts.alt: Barcode Scanning Notice in the Woo Mobile App
contexts.context: [Preceding: Many scanners will be configured in a compatible mode by default. You can ensure that your scanner is configured correctly by referring to the scanner’s manual. The scanner should be set up to use Bluetooth HID, and to send carriage return and line feed characters (/r or /r/n) at the end of each code.]

contexts.alt: Item added to Cart after a successful scan.
contexts.context: [Preceding: If a scan is successful, the corresponding product will be added to the Cart.]

contexts.alt: Scanned code error displayed after scanning a barcode not available in connected store.
contexts.context: [Preceding: If the scan is unsuccessful, the barcode number will be added to the cart with the error Unknown scanned item. This item can be removed from the Cart by selecting the Trash icon next to it.]

contexts.alt: WooCommerce provides a range of settings found at WooCommerce > Settings > Products > Approved Downl
contexts.context: [Preceding: WooCommerce provides a range of settings found at WooCommerce > Settings > Products > Approved Download Directories to help site administrators exercise control over the locations used for storing and serving product downloads.]

contexts.alt: To emphasize, only site administrators have the power to modify this list (or, in the context of mul
contexts.context: [Preceding: To emphasize, only site administrators have the power to modify this list (or, in the context of multisite networks, network administrators), and nobody else is able to add downloadable files to products unless there is a corresponding entry on this page.]

contexts.alt: The Stop / Start Enforcing Rules button near the top of the settings screen toggles the enforcement
contexts.context: [Preceding: The Stop / Start Enforcing Rules button near the top of the settings screen toggles the enforcement of the rules for cases where management of approved directories proves impractical. For example, if the person adding all the images has a “shop manager” role instead of an “Administrator” role.]

contexts.alt: There may be occasions when, as site administrator, you find you need additional control over this f
contexts.context: [Preceding: There may be occasions when, as site administrator, you find you need additional control over this functionality. For instance, if you import product data using some method other than our official importer tool, then the creation of new download paths may not initially be noticed by WooCommerce. For this reason, a couple of extra tools can be found in WooCommerce > Status > Tools:]

contexts.alt: In these cases, the affected downloadable files will also be marked as disabled with a red asterisk
contexts.context: [Preceding: In these cases, the affected downloadable files will also be marked as disabled with a red asterisk that appear to the right of the File URL field.]

contexts.alt: Select Search Bar to Enable Product Search in POS Mode
contexts.context: [Preceding: To search for a specific product, select the magnifying glass icon in the upper-right corner of the Products view.]

contexts.alt: Select Search Bar to Enable Product Search in POS Mode
contexts.context: [Preceding: This will open a search box and present your recent searches. Enter your search query to display products that match your search.]

contexts.alt: Coupon View in Woo Mobile App POS Mode
contexts.context: [Preceding: To create, manage, or add a coupon, select the Coupon button in the top left of your screen.]

contexts.alt: Coupon Added View in Woo Mobile App POS Mode
contexts.context: [Preceding: To add one of the available coupons to the current cart, tap it in the Coupon column. You can add multiple coupons.]

contexts.alt: Woo Mobile Add Coupon Screen POS Mode
contexts.context: [Preceding: If there are no coupons available, you will see the “No coupons found” error message. To create a new Coupon, select “Create Coupon” or select the “Plus” button in the upper-right corner of the Coupon view.]

contexts.alt: POS Mode Validating Coupon Screen
contexts.context: [Preceding: After coupons are added to the cart, they will need to be validated before you can check out. Select “Check Out” to begin the checkout process and validate your coupons. This process checks if the coupons can be used with the current products in the cart, and what the discount and transaction total are.]

contexts.alt: Coupon Successfully Added to Cart in POS Mode
contexts.context: [Preceding: Once your added Coupons have been validated, you will be able to proceed with the checkout, or presented with an error message indicating why the Coupon could not be applied to the cart.]

contexts.alt: Woo Mobile App Point of Sale Mode Connect Card Reader
contexts.context: [Preceding: When the order is ready to be paid for, tap the Check out button to proceed. POS mode will calculate the subtotal, taxes, and total price for the order. You can check out using a card reader which will begin connecting, or select Cash payment.]

contexts.alt: Point of Sale Mode Checkout screen connected to card reader.
contexts.context: [Preceding: To check out with a compatible Card reader, connect the card reader to your device.]

contexts.alt: Point of Sale Mode screenshot of successful payment during checkout.
contexts.context: [Preceding: Once the reader is ready, the customer can tap, swipe, or insert their card to pay for their order. If successful, the following screen will be shown:]

contexts.alt: Point of Sale Mode screenshot of failed payment during checkout.
contexts.context: [Preceding: If payment fails for some reason, POS mode will show a button you can tap to have the customer try a different payment method.]

contexts.alt: Woo Mobile Point of Sale Mode Cash Payment screen with change due.
contexts.context: [Preceding: After selecting Cash Payment, you will be prompted to input the amount of cash received. If the cash amount is larger than the amount owed, Woo Mobile will show you the change due for the transaction.]

contexts.alt: Woo Mobile Point of Sale Mode Email Receipt screen with email address.
contexts.context: [Preceding: After a successful transaction you can email a receipt to your customer by selecting Email receipt. The app will prompt you for your customers email address, and will send the receipt when you select Send.]

contexts.alt: paypal-standard-internal-server-error
contexts.context: [Preceding: If you see the following error message after hitting the purchase button, the email address you entered in PayPal settings is incorrect:]

[Preceding: WooCommerce uses an “invoice” system. There is a setting that “blocks duplicate invoices.” With two websites using invoices, it is inevitable that there will be duplicate invoice numbers. By de-selecting that setting in PayPal, the invoices have no issue. Please check that the Invoice Prefix in your WooCommerce PayPal settings is different for each site.]

[Preceding: Alternatively, to disable duplicate invoice checking, log into your PayPal account and go to Profile > Profile and Settings > My Selling Preferences > Block Payments (or) Payment Receiving Preferences and set Block accidental payments to “No.“]

contexts.alt: Once logged in select the gear icon in the top right to get to the My Profile page
contexts.context: [Preceding: Once logged in select the gear icon in the top right to get to the My Profile page. Then head to the Products & Services section and select Website Preferences. Once there toggle on the PayPal Account Optional option. To learn more, see: PayPal’s Website.]

contexts.alt: If data in the app isn’t loading as expected, you’ll first want to make sure that the WooCommerce da
contexts.context: [Preceding: If data in the app isn’t loading as expected, you’ll first want to make sure that the WooCommerce database doesn’t need an update. You can verify the WooCommerce database version by going to WooCommerce>Status from your site’s dashboard and ensuring the WooCommerce database version matches the version of WooCommerce installed on the site:]

contexts.alt: If data in the app isn’t loading as expected, you’ll first want to make sure that the WooCommerce da
contexts.context: [Preceding: If data in the app isn’t loading as expected, you’ll first want to make sure that the WooCommerce database doesn’t need an update. You can verify the WooCommerce database version by going to WooCommerce>Status from your site’s dashboard and ensuring the WooCommerce database version matches the version of WooCommerce installed on the site:]

contexts.alt: If the WooCommerce database is updated, one of the plugins on your site may be causing the issues yo
contexts.context: [Preceding: If the WooCommerce database is updated, one of the plugins on your site may be causing the issues you’re experiencing. In that case, we recommend disabling all of your plugins except for WooCommerce and Jetpack (if you’re using the Jetpack connection within the app) and then testing the app. If it works, turn on the plugins one at a time and test the app after each activation to find the plugin blocking the mobile app. We suggest starting with caching or security plugins, as they typically cause issues.]

contexts.alt: To check the maximum upload file size, click Media > Add New Media File from your WordPress dashboar
contexts.context: [Preceding: To check the maximum upload file size, click Media > Add New Media File from your WordPress dashboard. The maximum upload file size is shown at the bottom of the upload window, as shown in the screenshot.]

contexts.alt: The storage amount and limit displayed in the 'My Site' section of a WordPress.com user dashboard.
contexts.context: [Preceding: If you’re using WordPress.com to host your site, navigate to My Site (or My Sites if you have more than one) and select Media from the left sidebar. This will display your storage limit and the amount you have already used.]

contexts.alt: The notifications screen in the WooCommerce Mobile App on an Android device.
contexts.context: [Preceding: In the Settings app, navigate to Notifications > App Notifications > WooCommerce. (This location may change depending on the Android device you are using.) Ensure that the All WooCommerce notifications option is toggled on.]

contexts.alt: Notifications screen in the WooCommerce Mobile App on an iOS device.
contexts.context: [Preceding: In the Settings app, navigate to Notifications > WooCommerce and toggle the Allow Notifications option.]

contexts.alt: From your vendor dashboard, navigate to Submissions > Submit Product and select the product type you
contexts.context: [Preceding: From your vendor dashboard, navigate to Submissions > Submit Product and select the product type you’re planning to submit:]

contexts.alt: The information reuired varies slightly depending on the submission flow selected
contexts.context: [Preceding: The information reuired varies slightly depending on the submission flow selected. To help streamline the submission process, we only ask for critical details:]

contexts.alt: Next, address any submission test failures noted in the discussion dialog
contexts.context: [Preceding: Next, address any submission test failures noted in the discussion dialog. In the event of failures — marked as Failed — please click the View link beside the failed test to review the results and upload a modified version of your submission.]

contexts.alt: To proceed, click the Replace button to replace the current
contexts.context: [Preceding: To proceed, click the Replace button to replace the current .zip file with a corrected version. This will automatically restart the testing process.]

contexts.alt: For additional questions related to your submission, please use the discussion box below the Submiss
contexts.context: [Preceding: For additional questions related to your submission, please use the discussion box below the Submission Bot results table in the Submission progress tab.]

contexts.alt: Navigate to SaaS Apps to view the list of applications
contexts.context: [Preceding: Navigate to SaaS Apps to view the list of applications. You’ll likely have only one.]

contexts.alt: To access the application’s settings, click on the API key
contexts.context: [Preceding: To access the application’s settings, click on the API key. On the settings page, you can view and copy your API key and secret, generate a new API key & secret pair, and add/edit/remove the webhook URL associated with your application.]

contexts.alt: The flow for completing a purchase using WooCommerce
contexts.context: [Caption: The flow for completing a purchase using WooCommerce.com’s Billing API]

contexts.alt: View pending refund requests for your SaaS applications
contexts.context: [Caption: View pending refund requests for your SaaS applications]

contexts.alt: Input any contract UUID you’d like to test webhook calls against in the form and hit enter or click
contexts.context: [Preceding: Input any contract UUID you’d like to test webhook calls against in the form and hit enter or click on Select for testing. The page will reload with the contract selected. You can trigger webhook calls for the selected contract by clicking on the appropriate event button on the page. Please note that the available events depend on the current contract status. The webhook call is triggered async, so it may take up to a minute to receive the call. You can read more about the available webhook events in the webhooks section of this documentation. Make sure you have a webhook URL set up in your SaaS Application settings.]
